channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Documents at Mar-a-Lago Were Moved and Hidden as U.S. Sought Them, Filing Suggests
item.description: The filing by the Justice Department paints the clearest picture to date of its efforts to retrieve documents from the former president’s Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Charlie Savage, Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: The Justice Department included a photo of documents seized from former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida home in its court filing.

item.title: Hard Right Stokes Outrage After Search of Mar-a-Lago
item.description: As they did before the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, the former president and his allies are fueling anger among supporters.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump has often sought to demonize his adversaries.

item.title: L. Lin Wood, a Trump Ally, Is Called to Testify in Election-Meddling Inquiry
item.description: Mr. Wood said he would appear before the special grand jury in Atlanta.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.media:description: “I didn’t do anything wrong,” said L. Lin Wood, a trial lawyer. “I’ve got nothing to hide.”

item.title: Mikhail Gorbachev, Reformist Soviet Leader, Is Dead at 91
item.description: Adopting principles of glasnost and perestroika, he weighed the legacy of seven decades of Communist rule and set a new course, presiding over the end of the Cold War and the dissolution of the U.S.S.R.
item.dc:creator: Marilyn Berger
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev had a profound effect on his time: In little more than six tumultuous years, he lifted the Iron Curtain, transforming the map of Europe and the political climate of the world.

item.title: A Reporter’s Memories of Gorbachev, and That Pizza Hut Commercial
item.description: Anatoly Kurmanaev, a New York Times reporter, recalls a childhood forever changed by a man with a distinctive birthmark.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow in 1991.

item.title: US Life Expectancy Falls Again in ‘Historic’ Setback
item.description: The decline during the pandemic is the sharpest in nearly 100 years, hitting American Indian and Native Alaskan communities particularly hard.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: A patient who died of Covid was removed from an I.C.U. in Cleveland, Ohio.

item.title: Russia’s Occupation of Nuclear Plant Gives Moscow a New Way to Intimidate
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appears to be using the facility to scare Ukraine’s leaders and warn the West to stay out of the conflict.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russians say that the shelling near Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia power plant is coming from Ukrainian forces, and Ukraine’s government insists that Russian forces are responsible.

item.title: Russia halts natural gas flows to Germany again.
item.description: Gazprom said the Nord Stream 1 pipeline would undergo three days of maintenance, raising worries about a complete shutdown of Russian gas deliveries to Germany.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:description: Part of the Nord Stream 1 pipeline in Lubmin, Germany.

item.title: Death in Navy SEAL Training Exposes a Culture of Brutality, Cheating and Drugs
item.description: The elite force’s selection course is so punishing that few make it through, and many of those who do resort to illicit tactics.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Mississippi Governor Declares Emergency Over Drinking Water Crisis
item.description: In Jackson, residents have long contended with boil-water notices and service disruptions. But now, officials say, the system has been pushed to the brink.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Edmund D. Fountain for The New York Times

item.title: Lockdowns in China, and North Korea, Deal Double Blow to Bridge City
item.description: Shenyang, in China’s northeast, was a hub for North Korean workers and a launchpad for visits to Pyongyang. Covid restrictions have battered its economy.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Food stalls in Shenyang’s Koreatown. The city used to be a crucial link between China and North Korea, but the pandemic changed that.

item.title: Humpback Whales Pass Their Songs Across Oceans
item.description: Whales share songs from Australia to Ecuador, scientists have found, suggesting a remarkably fast cultural evolution.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: A humpback whale breaching in waters near Esmeraldas, Ecuador. Whales in Australia were found to be passing their songs to others in French Polynesia, which in turn gave songs to whales in Ecuador.

item.title: U.S. Will Set Aside Monkeypox Vaccines in New Equity Program
item.description: White House officials said an “equity intervention pilot” will get more doses to communities that have been left behind in the nation’s inoculation campaign.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A monkeypox vaccination in Tucson, Ariz., this month. A new program the White House announced Tuesday is aimed at increasing access to the shots.

item.title: In ‘Little Venice,’ Cruise Ships and an Influx of Tourists
item.description: With a ban on large cruise ships in the waters surrounding Venice, nearby Chioggia is one of the new go-to ports. While many welcome the new visitors, some worry that the tourism boom could turn sour.
item.dc:creator: Anna Momigliano
item.media:credit: Susan Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: The cruise ship Viking Sea in Chioggia’s port. Following a series of protests from environmental groups last year, the Italian government recently started enforcing a ban on large cruise ships from the portion of the lagoon surrounding Venice’s historic center. Chioggia is now one of the alternative ports.

item.title: Why Many Americans Turned on Anthony Fauci
item.description: A science worth following must lead.
item.dc:creator: Ari Schulman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Zisiga Mukulu/The New York Times; photograph by Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Jackie Chan Is Making a Movie in Syria. That’s a Problem.
item.description: The only trouble is, it’s not the real one.
item.dc:creator: Leila Al-Shami
item.media:credit: Louai Beshara/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Actors on a set of the Chinese film “Home Operation,” in Hajar al-Aswad, a Syrian suburb destroyed by the al-Assad regime.

item.title: Europe’s Gonna Party Like It’s 1979
item.description: Sometimes you just can’t let markets rip.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman

item.title: This Is the Other Way That History Ends
item.description: A once-scholarly discipline courts irrelevance in its desperate bid for relevance.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens

item.title: Bill Barr Made the Decision to Clear Trump, and That Should Still Frighten Us
item.description: The ability to investigate future high-level wrongdoing in the executive branch is at stake.
item.dc:creator: Neal K. Katyal
item.media:description: Donald Trump and Attorney General Bill Barr in 2019.

item.title: What It’s Like to Have Face Blindness
item.description: When you can’t rely on facial recognition, you look beyond the obvious.
item.dc:creator: James Robinson

item.title: Why I Changed My Mind on Student Debt Forgiveness
item.description: Our current system of student loans and college funding is at odds with what we hope to achieve by encouraging people to go to college.
item.dc:creator: Susan Dynarski
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; image by Nay Ni Ratn Mak Can Thuk/EyeEm, via Getty Images

item.title: The Book That Explains Our Cultural Stagnation
item.description: Art has gotten so boring. W. David Marx knows why.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: Status and Culture: How Our Desire for Social Rank Creates Taste, Identity, Art, Fashion, and Constant Change (Book)
item.media:credit: Calla Kessler for The New York Times
item.media:description: Partygoers at Art Basel Miami Beach.

item.title: Where to Host Your Birthday in NYC
item.description: Here’s where to host a group birthday dinner, whether it’s a park hang or an all-out fete.
item.dc:creator: Becky Hughes
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nothing screams “festivities” quite like a Dungeness crab on a lazy susan (especially this one at Wu’s Wonton King).

item.title: Jared Kushner’s Soulless Memoir and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

item.title: Why Pakistan Was Hit So Hard By Floods
item.description: Floods have killed at least 1,100 and submerged about a third of the country. We explain the factors making it so bad.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:description: Nowshera District, in northwestern Pakistan, on Tuesday.

item.title: Introducing ‘The Run-Up,’ a Politics Podcast from The New York Times
item.description: The midterm elections are usually a referendum on the party in power. This year, they’re about so much more.

item.title: Biden Calls Out G.O.P. on Guns, Crime and ‘Sickening’ Attacks on the F.B.I.
item.description: President Biden took what have been political vulnerabilities for the White House — policing and rising crime — and portrayed them as strengths ahead of the congressional elections in November.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: During his trip to Pennsylvania on Tuesday, President Biden highlighted a bipartisan gun bill intended to prevent dangerous people from accessing firearms.

item.title: For Venus and Serena Williams at the U.S. Open, Day and Night Experiences
item.description: Unlike her sister, Venus was not prepared to deal with questions about her tennis future after a loss in the first round of the singles tournament. “I’m just focused on the doubles,” she said.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venus Williams lost in the first round to Alison Van Uytvanck of Belgium in straight sets.

item.title: Washington Post’s Business Struggles as Frustrations Mount
item.description: With digital subscriptions and digital advertising revenue stagnating, the company is on a pace to lose money this year.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
item.media:description: Fred Ryan, the chief executive and publisher of The Washington Post, with Sally Buzbee, the executive editor, left.

item.title: West Point Has a K.K.K. Plaque Mounted Above Entrance to Science Hall
item.description: A special congressional commission that recommends the removal of Confederate symbols at U.S. military sites flagged the bronze plaque in a new report.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The U.S. Military Academy at West Point. A congressional panel flagged a plaque mounted at the entrance of Bartlett Hall Science Center that includes an image of a hooded figure and the words “Ku Klux Klan.”

item.title: More Children Are Swallowing Batteries and Landing in the E.R.
item.description: Twice as many kids needed treatment after putting button batteries in their mouths, noses and ears compared with the previous decade, a new study says. Here’s how to prevent it, and what to do if it happens.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: Why Chosen Families are Important for L.G.B.T.Q. People
item.description: For L.G.B.T.Q. people, the bonds between friends can be liberating and transformative. Five of these close-knit communities tell their stories.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Covid Vaccines for Kids Are Dividing Divorced Parents
item.description: For some parents who share custody, the Covid vaccine has created a minefield of issues that initial divorce decrees could not have anticipated.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin

item.title: Feeling Ambivalent About Motherhood Is Normal
item.description: After years of engaging with parenthood from a distance, it’s time for a psychiatrist specializing in women’s mental health to take her own advice.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Lakshmin, M.D.

item.title: Kids Are Using Social Media More Than Ever, Study Finds
item.description: The report highlights a 17 percent increase in screen use among teens and tweens in the last two years — more than in the four years prior.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: Ayo Edebiri and Her Dog Gromit Go to the Bookstore
item.description: A morning out in Los Angeles with the surprise star of “The Bear” and her Chihuahua mix.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Gabriella Angotti-Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: The writer, actress and comedian Ayo Edebiri at Skylight Books in Los Angeles.
